comment_text: Pov: odra

Aluminum Amalgam Reduction
(With your HgCl2)

I believe that this salt was used for treating syphilis topically (I do not believe it was meant to be taken internally). But here's something interesting: it was used to "denature" industrial alcohol during Prohibition -- to make it poisonous and really taste horrible. However, the bootleggers hired chemists to remove the compound from the alcohol (at least partially) and I may have read that amateur non-chemists tried filtering the stuff out using bread which may have improved the taste but I hate to think how bad it was for people who drank it.

Mind you, this was the government poisoning alcohol. Note too that even if no one actually drank the alcohol, it was probably pretty dangerous stuff to handle. And if it was used, for example, to clean surfaces, mercury chloride was probably left behind.

Apparently mercury(ii)chloride was often bought by magicians so a little could be discreetly added to a piece of aluminium foil which was then "scrunched up" and placed in someones hand. Usually after the magician had licked his finger and then made sure the foil was "damp". The mercury (ii) chloride then reacted with the aluminium foil to generate a LOT of heat.

Different patter was to try to convince the subject that he was being hypnotised into thinking it was hot - or that the magician had some strange ability to make it hot.

Often referred to simply as the "Hot Foil Trick", it was a trick that was not without risk.

How about doing some experiments that can help people survive if all modern amenities were gone? You know. Things like preserving food,  purifying water, refrigeration and generating  electricity. I think that people in general love to see, who, what, when, where and how to live without modern technology.

Back in the 1840's and up through the civil war, fulminate of mercury was used to make primers for the newly created sealed metallic cartridges. The Mercury was mixed with nitric acid to create a compound that is highly pressure sensitive. Thus, when struck by the firing pin of a firearm, the resulting shock/pressure wave is great enough to cause the primer to ignite, which in turn ignited the gunpowder within the cartridge. My main question is this. Was the material you just made, pressure sensitive at any stage of the process? My supposition is that, during the very first step in the process, fulminate of mercury would be produced. Is the orange gas created during the chemical reactions, explosive as well? Thanks for your time and awesome experiments.

The true reaction between mercury and nitric acid generates colourles NO, not NO₂. You can see that from the video, where the red-brownish colour becomes visible just when the NO gas escapes from the flask and reacts with air. So the stoichioetric ratio to dissolve liquid mercury in HNO₃ is 3Hg + 8HNO₃, not 1 : 4.

In pharmaceutical formulation, HgCl2 is used to ID test stannous chloride (SnCl2) before using it in a product. The reaction between these two salt solutions is a classic redox that precipitates elemental mercury:

SnCl2 + HgCl2 --> SnCl4 + Hg

Mercuric chloride was used by Madge Oberholtzer to commit suicide after she was kidnapped, raped, and tortured by Ku Klux Klan leader D.C. Stephenson. Oberholtzer died from a combination of mercury poisoning and staph infection, the latter caused by Stephenson biting her during the assault.[16]

Your chloride is most likely contaminated with nitrate.  Why not use only hydrochloric acid with hydrogen peroxide in excess to drive it forward?  This way the only contamination is water and unreacted HCL, both which can be driven off with heating.

An aluminium and mercury amalgam was prepared by the addition of mercuric chloride (6 mg) to freshly-cut aluminium foil (250 mg) in H2O (18 mL).
Once amalgamation was complete the H2O was decanted and the aluminium was washed with H2O (2 × 30 mL).
To the aluminium amalgam was sequentially added methylamine hydrochloride (375 mg) in H2O(375μL), isopropanol (1.1 mL), 25% aqueous sodium hydroxide (880μL) and 3,4-methylenedioxyphenyl-2-propanone(330 mg, 1.85 mmol) in isopropanol (2.2 mL).
The reaction was kept below 50 °C and stirred overnight before being extracted with dichloromethane (3 × 50 ml).
The combined organic extracts were dried (MgSO4) and concentrated under reduced pressure to yield 3,4-methylenedioxy-methamphetamine (300 mg, 84%) as a yellow oil.

You can use Gallium chloride and gallium indium alloy with tin (II) chloride instead of toxic mercuric chloride!

The tin (II) chloride attacks the aluminum oxide layer of aluminum foil!
Tin metal is left behind and fuses with the gallium indium alloy!
Then the gallium indium tin liquid alloy can amalgamate the rest of the elemental aluminum underneath in the aluminum foil!
Then the aluminum splits the hydrogen oxide(H2O, Water) into hydrogen gas and aluminum hydroxide.
The galinstan(gallium indium tin) liquid alloy can then pool at the bottom and can be recovered.
To bead up the gallium based alloy, you can add dilute sulfuric acid.
The synthesis of gallium (III) chloride:
This must be done outside while wearing a gas mask.
Method 1.
First, you pour nitric acid in a beaker.
Then you add melted liquid gallium metal.
Then you can heat up the solution.
It will fume nitrogen dioxide gases.
Then you get gallium nitrate.
You can the purify it.
Use the gallium nitrate and heat it up to around 250°C to 500°C to decompose it to Gallium oxide.
Then you take the gallium oxide and then react it with hydrochloric acid or thionyl chloride to make gallium (III) chloride.
If thionyl chloride is used, then sulfer dioxide gases are emitted!
Method 2.
This must be done outside while wearing a gas mask.
You get melted gallium metal.
You put it in a beaker.
Then add hydrochloric acid.
Then add nitric acid.
The nitric acid will attack the surface of the gallium.
Then the hydrochloric acid can turn it into gallium (III) chloride.
Then you can isolate it.

Note:
If you use gallium indium liquid alloy as a starting material, you will get a mixture of gallium (III) chloride and Indium (III) chloride.

The HgCl2 you made is contaminated with Hg(NO3)2. The decomposition of your mercuric nitrate was far from complete. mercuric oxide is bright red, in your video you see a pale red product with white chunks in it. I think your mercuric chloride is not even 50% pure.

You should have precitipated mercuric oxide from your Hg(NO3)2 solution by adding NaOH, followed by filtering and repeated washing. This can then be dissolved into HCl. The only disadvantage to this method is that you get some low level mercury (filtrate and washings) waste as a byproduct.

Also, I recommend covering your flask with tissue paper when you dissolve mercury. Apart from nitrogen dioxide, a fine mist of extremely small droplets is released containing mercury-ions.

Nile, if you want something really cool, you can synthesise diphenylmercury out of mercury(II) chloride or phenylmercury chloride. I'm not suggesting making dimethylmercury, it's just too scary! Actually it is more convienient to use a base to percipatate out the mercury(II)-oxide. Just put 50% NaOH into the mercury (II)-nitrate solution and nice red mercury (II)-oxide percipitates immediately.

I was wondering whether you tested your mercury II chloride for presence of nitrate ions.

The conversion from Hg(NO3)2 to HgO was not complete, as shown by the NO2 evolution while drying your HgCl2 (It was visibly white at some spots like you mentioned as well). Seeing the Hg(NO3)2 decomposition was not complete the first time, i assume it wont be complete the second time either. Which means you probably still have some NO3 ions in your HgCl2 product. This could interfere in future experiments, depending on the nature of the reaction. (This will also slightly increase your apparent Hg(NO3)2 yield because NO3 is a bit heavier than Cl.)
